elements.content: Three magnesium based metal–organic frameworks, Mg3(3,5-PDC)3(DMF)3·DMF [1], Mg(3,5-PDC)(H2O)·(H2O) [3], and Mg4(3,5-PDC)4(DMF)2(H2O)2·2DMF·4.5H2O [4], and a 2-D coordination polymer, [Mg(3,5-PDC)(H2O)2] [2] [PDC = pyridinedicarboxylate], were synthesized using a combination of DMF, methanol, ethanol, and water. Compound 1 [space group P21/n, a = 12.3475(5) Å, b = 11.1929(5) Å, c = 28.6734(12) Å, β = 98.8160(10)°, V = 3916.0(3) Å3] consists of a combination of isolated and corner-sharing magnesium octahedra connected by the organic linkers to form a 3-D network with a 12.2 Å × 4.6 Å 1-D channel. The channel contains coordinated and free DMF molecules. In compound 2 [space group C2/c, a = 9.964(5) Å, b = 12.0694(6) Å, c = 7.2763(4) Å, β = 106.4970(6)°, V = 836.70(6) Å3], PDC connects isolated seven coordinated magnesium polyhedra into a layered structure. Compound 3 [space group P6122, a = 11.479(1) Å, c = 14.735(3) Å, V = 1681.7(4) Å3] (previously reported) contains isolated magnesium octahedra connected by the organic linker with each other forming a 3D network. Compound 4 [space group P21/c, a = 13.7442(14) Å, b = 14.2887(15) Å, c = 14.1178(14) Å, β = 104.912(2)°, V = 2679.2(5) Å3] also exhibits a 3D network based on isolated magnesium octahedra with square cavities containing both disordered DMF and water molecules. The structural topologies originate due to the variable coordination ability of solvent molecules with the metal center. Water molecules coordinate with the magnesium metal centers preferably over other polar solvents (DMF, methanol, ethanol) used to synthesize the coordination networks. Despite testing multiple desolvation routes, we were unable to measure BET surface areas greater than 51.9 m2/g for compound 1.

elements.content: Four magnesium-3,5-pyridinedicarboxylate coordination networks were synthesized using different solvents and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction techniques. The variable coordination abilities of the solvents with the metal center play the primary role in the formation of the networks of different topologies and thermal behavior.
elements.clean_text: Four magnesium-3,5-pyridinedicarboxylate coordination networks were synthesized using different solvents and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction techniques. The variable coordination abilities of the solvents with the metal center play the primary role in the formation of the networks of different topologies and thermal behavior.

elements.content: Because of their potential application in gas storage, separation, catalysis, and conductivity, the discovery of new metal organic frameworks (MOFs) or coordination polymers is of great topical interest. The structural chemistry of MOFs covers a range of organic ligands and metal ions. First row transition metals are the most common metal ions to construct coordination networks, due in large part to their well-known bonding interactions with carboxylates. Recently, networks built with lightweight metal ions (Li, Mg, B) have been explored, due to their potential gravimetric advantage for gas storage applications.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Because of their potential application in gas storage, separation, catalysis, and conductivity, the discovery of new metal organic frameworks (MOFs) or coordination polymers is of great topical interest. The structural chemistry of MOFs covers a range of organic ligands and metal ions. First row transition metals are the most common metal ions to construct coordination networks, due in large part to their well-known bonding interactions with carboxylates. Recently, networks built with lightweight metal ions (Li, Mg, B) have been explored, due to their potential gravimetric advantage for gas storage applications.

elements.content: The choice of organic linkers and solvents are critical parameters for varying the coordination behavior of metal ions and determining the overall characteristics of the network. The isomers of pyridine dicarboxylic acids form a variety of network topologies with first row transition and lanthanide metal ions because of their diverse coordination modes utilizing carboxylate oxygen atoms and pyridyl nitrogen. Solvent often influences the coordination behavior of the metal ions, and this behavior may determine the connectivity and dimensionality of the overall framework. The extent of deprotonation of organic carboxylate linkers that largely decide its coordination mode can be controlled by adjusting the basicity of the solvent medium. Extraframework solvent molecules can also influence the thermal and desolvation properties via intermolecular interaction with the parent network.

Extraframework solvent molecules can also influence the thermal and desolvation properties via intermolecular interaction with the parent network.

elements.content: We are currently investigating the structure type and functionalities of different networks formed by using ultralight (Li) and light (Mg) coordination centers for potential use as gas storage media. In this article, we report the solvent-dependent formation of coordination networks based on magnesium metal ions and 3,5-pyrdinedicarboxylate (PDC) as the organic linker: 3-D frameworks, Mg3(3,5-PDC)3(DMF)3·DMF [1], Mg(PDC)(H2O)·(H2O) [3], and Mg4(3,5-PDC)4(DMF)2(H2O)2·2DMF·4.5H2O [4], formed in DMF, DMF/ethanol, and DMF/methanol, respectively, and a 2-D polymer, Mg(3,5-PDC)(H2O)2 [2], formed in ethanol or water.

elements.content: Compounds 1–4 were synthesized under solvothermal conditions using Teflon-lined 23-mL Parr stainless steel autoclaves. Starting materials include magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich), 3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (C7H3O4N, 3,5-PDC, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich), N,N-dimethylformamide (C3H7NO, DMF, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich), ethanol (C2H5OH, 95%, Fisher), and methanol (CH3OH, 99.8%, Sigma-Aldrich). Ethanol and methanol were dried overnight over calcium oxide (CaO) before use as reaction solvent.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

Compounds 1-4 were synthesized under solvothermal conditions using Teflon-lined 23-mL Parr stainless steel autoclaves. Starting materials include magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich), 3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (C7H3O4N, 3,5-PDC, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich), N,N-dimethylformamide (C3H7NO, DMF, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich), ethanol (C2H5OH, 95%, Fisher), and methanol (CH3OH, 99.8%, Sigma-Aldrich). Ethanol and methanol were dried overnight over calcium oxide (CaO) before use as reaction solvent.

elements.content: A typical synthesis includes a mixture of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O (0.258 g) and 3,5-PDC (0.17 g) dissolved in 9.5 g of DMF and stirred for 3 h to achieve homogeneity [molar ratio of metal salt/ligand/solvent = 1:1:130]. The resultant solution was heated for 5 days at 100 °C, and the product (yield: 60% based on Mg, 0.172 g) was collected as needle shaped crystals by filtration and washed by DMF.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Compound 1, Mg3(3,5-PDC)3(DMF)3⋅DMF

A typical synthesis includes a mixture of Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.258 g) and 3,5-PDC (0.17 g) dissolved in 9.5 g of DMF and stirred for 3 h to achieve homogeneity [molar ratio of metal salt/ligand/solvent = 1:1:130]. The resultant solution was heated for 5 days at 100 °C, and the product (yield: 60% based on Mg, 0.172 g) was collected as needle shaped crystals by filtration and washed by DMF.

elements.content: Compound 2 was synthesized from a mixture of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O (0.255 g) and 3,5-PDC (0.167 g) dissolved in 6 g of ethanol, which was stirred for 2 h [molar ratio of metal salt/ligand/solvent = 1:1:130]. The resultant solution was heated for 5 days at 100 °C. The product was collected as needle shaped crystals (yield: 50% based on Mg, 0.112 g) by filtration and rinsed with ethanol.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Compound 2, Mg(3,5-PDC)(H2O)2 

Compound 2 was synthesized from a mixture of Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.255 g) and 3,5-PDC (0.167 g) dissolved in 6 g of ethanol, which was stirred for 2 h [molar ratio of metal salt/ligand/solvent = 1:1:130]. The resultant solution was heated for 5 days at 100 °C. The product was collected as needle shaped crystals (yield: 50% based on Mg, 0.112 g) by filtration and rinsed with ethanol.

elements.content: Compound 3 was synthesized by dissolving Mg(NO3)2·6H2O (0.257 g) and 3,5-PDC (0.168 g) in a mixture of DMF (4.7 g) and ethanol (2.99 g) and stirred for 1 h [molar ratio of metal salt/ligand/DMF/ethanol = 1:1:65:65]. The resulting solution was heated for 5 days at 100 °C. The product was obtained as crystalline material (yield 60% based on Mg, 0.135 g) by filtration and washed with ethanol.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Compound 3, Mg(3,5-PDC)(H2O)⋅(H2O)

Compound 3 was synthesized by dissolving Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.257 g) and 3,5-PDC (0.168 g) in a mixture of DMF (4.7 g) and ethanol (2.99 g) and stirred for 1 h [molar ratio of metal salt/ligand/DMF/ethanol = 1:1:65:65]. The resulting solution was heated for 5 days at 100 °C. The product was obtained as crystalline material (yield 60% based on Mg, 0.135 g) by filtration and washed with ethanol.

elements.content: Compound 4 was synthesized by dissolving Mg(NO3)2·6H2O (0.261 g) and 3,5-PDC (0.171 g) in a mixture of DMF (4.7 g) and ethanol (2.08 g) and stirred for 2 h to achieve homogeneity [molar ratio of metal salt/ligand/DMF/methanol = 1:1:65:65]. The resulting solution was heated for 5 days at 100 °C. A yellow phase was collected by filtration as a side product along with needle shaped crystals of compound 4. Efforts to obtain a pure phase of compound 4 by (a) increasing reaction temperature or (b) increasing solvent ratio were not successful.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Compound 4, Mg4(3,5-PDC)4(DMF)2(H2O)2⋅2DMF⋅4.5H2O

Compound 4 was synthesized by dissolving Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.261 g) and 3,5-PDC (0.171 g) in a mixture of DMF (4.7 g) and ethanol (2.08 g) and stirred for 2 h to achieve homogeneity [molar ratio of metal salt/ligand/DMF/methanol = 1:1:65:65]. The resulting solution was heated for 5 days at 100 °C. A yellow phase was collected by filtration as a side product along with needle shaped crystals of compound 4. Efforts to obtain a pure phase of compound 4 by (a) increasing reaction temperature or (b) increasing solvent ratio were not successful.

elements.content: Suitable crystals of compounds 1–4 were selected from then bulk samples and were mounted on glass fibers using epoxy adhesive. The microcrystalline nature of the compounds 1 and 2 formed under the reaction conditions described above prevented full structure elucidation from data collected on in-house X-ray sources. Synchrotron X-ray sources at the Advanced Photon Source ChemMatCars beamline and at the Advanced Light Source 11.3.1 microcrystal diffraction beamline were used to collect low temperature (100 K) single crystal diffraction data for compounds 1 and 2, respectively. Reflection data for compound 1 were collected using a three-circle Bruker D8 diffractometer equipped with an APEXII detector (λ = 0.41328 Å) with 0.5° φ scans. The raw intensity data were analyzed using the APEXII suite of programs and were corrected for absorption effects using SADABS. Reflection data for compound 2 were collected using 180° ω scans, at 0.3° steps, with settings of φ = 90°, 180°, and 270° on a similar instrument to that described for 1, using X-rays with λ = 0.7749 Å. For compound 2, the program Cell_Now identified a 2-component twin with domains related by a 180° rotation about reciprocal axis [0 1 1]*. The data were integrated using APEXII software, using the orientation matrices for both twin components and were corrected for absorption effects using TWINABS. The intensity data were output in both SHELX HKLF4 and HKLF5 file formats.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Suitable crystals of compounds 1-4 were selected from then bulk samples and were mounted on glass fibers using epoxy adhesive. The microcrystalline nature of the compounds 1 and 2 formed under the reaction conditions described above prevented full structure elucidation from data collected on in-house X-ray sources. Synchrotron X-ray sources at the Advanced Photon Source ChemMatCars beamline and at the Advanced Light Source 11.3.1 microcrystal diffraction beamline were used to collect low temperature (100 K) single crystal diffraction data for compounds 1 and 2, respectively. Reflection data for compound 1 were collected using a three-circle Bruker D8 diffractometer equipped with an APEXII detector (λ = 0.41328 Å) with 0.5° φ scans. The raw intensity data were analyzed using the APEXII suite of programs and were corrected for absorption effects using SADABS. Reflection data for compound 2 were collected using 180° ω scans, at 0.3° steps, with settings of φ = 90°, 180°, and 270° on a similar instrument to that described for 1, using X-rays with λ = 0.7749 Å. For compound 2, the program Cell_Now identified a 2-component twin with domains related by a 180° rotation about reciprocal axis [0 1 1]*. The data were integrated using APEXII software, using the orientation matrices for both twin components and were corrected for absorption effects using TWINABS. The intensity data were output in both SHELX HKLF4 and HKLF5 file formats.

elements.content: Reflections for compounds 3 and 4 were collected using a Bruker four circle P4 single crystal diffractometer equipped with a SMART 1K CCD detector at room temperature (298 K) with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and φ and ω scans. The raw intensity data were collected and integrated with the software packages SMART and SAINT, respectively. An empirical absorption correction was applied using SADABS.

The raw intensity data were collected and integrated with the software packages SMART and SAINT, respectively. An empirical absorption correction was applied using SADABS.

elements.content: The structures were solved using direct methods and were refined using SHELXL. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically with the hydrogen atoms placed in idealized positions using geometrical constraints. Four DMF molecules are present in the asymmetric unit of compound 1. Three of them are coordinated to metal ions, and one is present in an uncoordinated state within the channel. The uncoordinated and two of the coordinated DMF molecules are found disordered and were modeled using the PART command in SHELXL. The coordinated DMF molecules were found disordered over the C, N positions with site occupancies of 68.1(1)% and 54.7(1)% for the major component. The uncoordinated DMF molecule is disordered over all the atom positions, and site occupancy was refined to 61.8(1)% for the major component. Table lists the crystallographic parameters from the refinements of 1–4. The unit cell of compounds 3 and 4 contains highly disordered solvent molecules. We were not able to assign the residual electron density peaks in the case of compound 3. TGA-DSC data were used to determine the possible nature of the solvent species within the channel. For compound 4, the residual electron density peaks in the channel were assigned as heavily disordered water and DMF molecules.

Bulk sample identification and phase purity were determined using powder X-ray diffraction. The data were collected using a Scintag Pad-X diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5405 Å) radiation within the range 5° ≤ 2θ ≤ 40° (step size, 0.02°; counting time, 1 s/step). Comparison of the observed and calculated powder XRD patterns for 1 and 2 confirmed the phase purity ().

elements.content: The surface area measurement of compound 1 was carried out using a Quantachrome Nova 2200e surface area analyzer. To avoid structural collapse of the material due to rapid degassing, the sample was first evacuated at room temperature for one hour prior to increasing temperature at a rate of 1 °C/min to 200 °C. The sample was weighed after a 12-h degassing period. The 33% weight-loss with respect to the starting weight confirms the complete removal of both free and coordinated DMF molecules (expected: 32.3%). The surface area was calculated from a linear 5-point BET plot acquired from analysis at liquid N2 temperature (77 K) using N2 adsorbate gas.
elements.clean_text:
BET Measurement

The surface area measurement of compound 1 was carried out using a Quantachrome Nova 2200e surface area analyzer. To avoid structural collapse of the material due to rapid degassing, the sample was first evacuated at room temperature for one hour prior to increasing temperature at a rate of 1 °C/min to 200 °C. The sample was weighed after a 12-h degassing period. The 33% weight-loss with respect to the starting weight confirms the complete removal of both free and coordinated DMF molecules (expected: 32.3%). The surface area was calculated from a linear 5-point BET plot acquired from analysis at liquid N2 temperature (77 K) using N2 adsorbate gas.

Thermal Analysis

Combined TGA-DSC experiments for compounds 1-3 were performed using a Netzsch 449C Jupiter instrument. The samples were heated from room temperature to 750 °C under a N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min (Figures  -).

elements.content: There are three unique magnesium environments in compound 1; the Mg1-octahedron is isolated while Mg2 and Mg3 octahedra form a corner-sharing dimer. Three crystallographically independent PDC linkers bridge these magnesium atoms, forming a 3-D network decorated by four unique DMF molecules (Figure and Figure S4 of the ). All Mg-sites exhibit distorted octahedral coordination to carboxylate oxygen and pyridyl nitrogen atoms from the ligand as well as solvent DMF molecules with bond distances between 2.006(2) Å [Mg1–O6] and 2.237(2) Å [Mg3–N2]. Selected bond distances are summarized in Table . The bond valence sums of the magnesium ions are 2.163 v.u., 2.174 v.u., and 2.12 v.u. for sites Mg1, Mg2, and Mg3, respectively, matching the expected value of +2 v.u. (valence unit).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Description of 1, Mg3(3,5-PDC)3(DMF)3⋅DMF

There are three unique magnesium environments in compound 1; the Mg1-octahedron is isolated while Mg2 and Mg3 octahedra form a corner-sharing dimer. Three crystallographically independent PDC linkers bridge these magnesium atoms, forming a 3-D network decorated by four unique DMF molecules (Figure  and Figure S4 of the ). All Mg-sites exhibit distorted octahedral coordination to carboxylate oxygen and pyridyl nitrogen atoms from the ligand as well as solvent DMF molecules with bond distances between 2.006(2) Å [Mg1-O6] and 2.237(2) Å [Mg3-N2]. Selected bond distances are summarized in Table . The bond valence sums of the magnesium ions are 2.163 v.u., 2.174 v.u., and 2.12 v.u. for sites Mg1, Mg2, and Mg3, respectively, matching the expected value of +2 v.u. (valence unit).

The isolated magnesium octahedra is connected with the dimeric corner sharing magnesium octahedra through carboxylate oxygen atoms along the [010] direction (Figure S8 of the ). The magnesium polyhedra are further connected in the [100] and [001] directions through pyridyl nitrogen and carboxylate oxygen atoms of PDC linker forming channels filled with both coordinated and free DMF molecules. The solvent molecules exhibit various degrees of disorder. The dimensionalities of the channels are on average 12.2 Å × 4.6 Å along the [010] direction when calculated based on van der Waals radii in the absence of both coordinated and free DMF molecules in the channel. Calculations using PLATON indicate a 51.5% (2018.2 Å3) void space after removal of coordinated and free DMF molecules from the channel.

elements.content: Compound 2 consists of isolated Mg-centered polyhedra connected by the organic linkers to form a layered structure (Figure ). Selected bond distances are summarized in Table . The asymmetric unit of compound 2 consists of a crystallographically unique magnesium ion, a portion of the organic linker (3,5-PDC), and one water molecule bound to a magnesium metal center (). The magnesium ion, pyridyl nitrogen, and one carbon atom (C4) of the aromatic ring lie on special positions (Wyckoff position e, site symmetry 2) with a site occupancy factor of 1/2. The coordination environment for the magnesium is assigned to a rare pentagonal bipyramidal geometry, consistent with bond valence calculations (expected, 2.00; calculated, 1.94). Each magnesium ion connects with three organic ligands through bidentate chelating carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2, O3) and the pyridyl nitrogen (N8) (). Two water molecules are coordinated with the magnesium metal center with 2.04 Å average bond lengths.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description of 2, Mg(3,5-PDC)(H2O)2 

Compound 2 consists of isolated Mg-centered polyhedra connected by the organic linkers to form a layered structure (Figure ). Selected bond distances are summarized in Table . The asymmetric unit of compound 2 consists of a crystallographically unique magnesium ion, a portion of the organic linker (3,5-PDC), and one water molecule bound to a magnesium metal center (). The magnesium ion, pyridyl nitrogen, and one carbon atom (C4) of the aromatic ring lie on special positions (Wyckoff position e, site symmetry 2) with a site occupancy factor of 1/2. The coordination environment for the magnesium is assigned to a rare pentagonal bipyramidal geometry, consistent with bond valence calculations (expected, 2.00; calculated, 1.94). Each magnesium ion connects with three organic ligands through bidentate chelating carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2, O3) and the pyridyl nitrogen (N8) (). Two water molecules are coordinated with the magnesium metal center with 2.04 Å average bond lengths.

Each organic ligand is connected with three magnesium ions along the [110] and [−110] directions to form the basis of the layered network; Mg coordination sites that might lead to connectivity in the third dimension are occupied by terminal water molecules. The distances between successive layers are on average 3.64 Å along the [001] direction (Figure S11 of the ). No significant π–π packing occurs; instead, interlayer interactions are primarily through hydrogen bonds between the bound water molecule (O1w) and the carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2, O3) in the adjacent layer (O–O distances 2.751 Å and 2.761 Å).

elements.content: Compound 3 contains isolated magnesium-centered octahedra connected by the organic linkers to form a 3-D network (Figure ). The asymmetric unit of compound 3 contains one crystallographically unique magnesium metal center, a portion of the organic linker (3,5-PDC), and one bound water molecule (Figure S12 of the ). The octahedral coordination of the magnesium center has contributions from four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O2), one pyridyl nitrogen (N1), and the oxygen atom from a coordinating water molecule (Figure S13 of the ). The bond distance varies between 2.025 Å (Mg1–O1) and 2.252 Å (Mg1–N1) with a bond valence sum for magnesium calculated as 2.17 v.u., matching well with the expected value of +2. Selected bond distances and angles are summarized in Table .

Each magnesium center in compound 3 is associated with five organic linkers through bonding with four carboxylate oxygen atoms and one pyridyl nitrogen. The other coordination is occupied by the oxygen atom of the water molecule. This type of connectivity leads to formation of a circular shaped channel of approximately 5.5 Å diameter along the [001] direction and containing a coordinated water molecule. Highly disordered solvent molecules are present within the void, accounting for approximately 36.7% (617 Å3) of the unit cell’s volume.

elements.content: Compound 4 is formed from a combination of corner sharing dimers of magnesium polyhedra, connected by organic linkers forming a 3-D network (Figure ). The asymmetric unit of compound 4 contains two crystallographically independent metal centers, two organic linkers along with a coordinated DMF and water molecule (Figure S14 of the ). Both the magnesium centers are present in distorted octahedral coordination with oxygen and nitrogen atoms of the ligand, and oxygen atoms from the coordinating water and DMF molecules, with bond distance varying between 1.986(2) Å [Mg2–O4] to 2.743(2) Å [Mg2–O7]. Selected interatomic distances are presented in Table . The bond valence sum of the magnesium metal centers (Mg1 and Mg2) are 2.212 v. u. and 2.1 v. u., respectively, matching well with the expected value of +2 v. u.

Each magnesium polyhedron is connected to each other one in corner sharing fashion through a carboxylate oxygen atom (O7), forming a dimer. Each dimer is further connected by functional groups (carboxylate oxygen atoms and pyridyl nitrogen) of the organic linkers in all three crystallographic directions. Such an arrangement leads to the formation of a diamond shaped 1-D channel with average size 8.5 Å × 3.5 Å. Coordinated and uncoordinated solvent molecules including DMF and water are present in the channel. PLATON indicates a 32.1% (858.7 Å3) void space after removal of free DMF and water molecules from the channel.

elements.content: The dimensionality of the networks produced in this study is determined by the coordination environment of magnesium, which is clearly dictated by the coordinating strength of the solvent molecules. A total of four different coordination networks were synthesized on the basis of selection of reaction solvents (Table ), while the other synthetic parameters were intentionally held constant. The reaction in pure DMF results in the formation of compound 1, while compound 2 forms in either pure ethanol or water. Surprisingly, carrying this reaction out in pure methanol results in clear solutions. Given the intermediate polarity and relative permittivity compared to water and ethanol, this is not an intuitive result. Frameworks 1 and 2 differ in that they contain water or DMF, respectively. Since water from the metal salts is present in sufficient quantities to hydrate, but at a much lower concentration than ethanol, we can conclude that solvation by water is more favorable than by ethanol, since no reactions resulted in ethanol-containing products. A range of solvent mixtures combining the four solvents were further used to determine the role of solvent on the formation of Mg-3,5-PDC networks. Water, when used in combination with other solvents (DMF, ethanol, methanol), always favored the formation of the hydrated compound 2, as evident from the PXRD (Table )
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

The dimensionality of the networks produced in this study is determined by the coordination environment of magnesium, which is clearly dictated by the coordinating strength of the solvent molecules. A total of four different coordination networks were synthesized on the basis of selection of reaction solvents (Table ), while the other synthetic parameters were intentionally held constant. The reaction in pure DMF results in the formation of compound 1, while compound 2 forms in either pure ethanol or water. Surprisingly, carrying this reaction out in pure methanol results in clear solutions. Given the intermediate polarity and relative permittivity compared to water and ethanol, this is not an intuitive result. Frameworks 1 and 2 differ in that they contain water or DMF, respectively. Since water from the metal salts is present in sufficient quantities to hydrate, but at a much lower concentration than ethanol, we can conclude that solvation by water is more favorable than by ethanol, since no reactions resulted in ethanol-containing products. A range of solvent mixtures combining the four solvents were further used to determine the role of solvent on the formation of Mg-3,5-PDC networks. Water, when used in combination with other solvents (DMF, ethanol, methanol), always favored the formation of the hydrated compound 2, as evident from the PXRD (Table )

The higher dimensionality of compound 3 compared to compound 2 primarily arises from the number of solvent water molecules present in the coordination sphere of the metal center. The presence of two terminal water molecules in the crystallographic [001] direction for compound 2 precludes extended connectivity in that direction, limiting covalent connectivity to two dimensions. The presence of a fifth metal coordination in compound 3 for the linker functional groups leads to the formation of a 3-D network, as the additional coordination site must be available perpendicular to the planar arrangement of PDC coordination sites seen in 2. The reason for lower water molecule coordination may relate to the better solubility and higher rate of deprotonation of the organic linker in the presence of DMF.

The reason for lower water molecule coordination may relate to the better solubility and higher rate of deprotonation of the organic linker in the presence of DMF.

elements.content: Moving this study further, a 1:1 mixture of DMF and methanol leads to the formation of compound 4 as the minor phase. While both DMF and water molecule are present within the network in coordinated and uncoordinated form, methanol is not incorporated in the network structure. Further characterization of 4 was not possible, as we were unable to synthesize this compound 4 in pure form, despite repeated efforts. The lack of metal coordination by methanol implies that coordination is again more favorable for water and DMF compared to small alcohols. Finally, the mutual coordination ability of methanol, ethanol, and DMF was compared using a mixture of three (DMF/ethanol/methanol: 1:1:1) and a mixture of two (methanol/ethanol: 1:1) solvents, respectively, under similar synthetic conditions. Compound 3 is the product when DMF, methanol, and ethanol are used in a 1:1:1 ratio. In only a few cases have we noticed the formation of both compound 2 and compound 3 together, possibly due to the presence of excess water in Teflon liners. Compound 2 forms exclusively when 1:1 methanol–ethanol mixtures are employed (Table )

elements.content: Thermal stabilities of compounds 1–3 were investigated using the combination of TGA and DSC techniques under N2 atmosphere. Compound 1 shows a ready removal of both coordinated and free DMF molecules up to 325 °C (calculated, 32.3%; observed, 33.1%), followed by pyrolysis of the ligand over 425 °C. Compound 2, on the other hand, shows a stepwise decomposition pathway (Figure 8). The first weight loss that occurs at 225 °C is due to the removal of water molecules (calculated, 15.9 wt %; observed, 16.1 wt %), followed by a stable plateau to 515 °C, where pyrolysis of the ligand occurs. Compound 3 shows similar two step decomposition pathways. In the first step, coordinated and free water molecules are removed (calculated, 15.9%; observed, 16%) in a continuous fashion within 225 °C. This step is followed by a stable plateau up to 520 °C followed by pyrolysis of the organic linker.

elements.content: Porous alkali- and alkaline-earth metal carboxylates are scarce. As compound 1 possesses a theoretical 51.5% (2018.2 Å3) void space, we attempted to activate a sample under dynamic vacuum at 200 °C. The powder diffraction pattern of the desolvated sample shows poor crystallinity (Figure S17 of the ) and a low BET surface area of 51.9 m2/g and a Langmuir surface area of 69.7 m2/g. The small surface area indicates destruction of network, which is also supported by the PXRD data. In a few reported cases, magnesium networks show nonporosity toward N2, due to smaller pore size, but show permanent porosity toward other gases, e.g. O2 and CO2 due to their smaller kinetic diameters. In this case, it is highly unlikely, as compound 1 does show adsorption of N2, as evident in the BET/Langmuir studies. Further, the PXRD pattern of desolvated compound 1 does not show retention of network.

elements.content: Compound 1 is soluble in water but insoluble in common organic solvents (e.g., acetone, methanol, ethanol, ethyl acetate, ether, and hexane). A solvent exchange study was performed on compound 1 to replace the DMF molecule in the channel with more volatile solvents (e.g., methanol, ethanol, acetonitrile, dichloromethane). We were only able to produce X-ray amorphous materials using solvent exchange (Figure S18 of the ). Compound 2 is also soluble in water but not soluble in organic solvents such as methanol, ethanol, and acetone. It forms a poorly crystalline product after removal of the coordinated water solvent, as evident from the powder XRD pattern (Figure S18 of the ). The desolvated compound 2 is also soluble in water but insoluble in ethanol. The powder XRD pattern of the desolvated compounds 1 and 2 soaked in DMF and ethanol, respectively, did not show any change in the structure, confirming the irreversibility of the phase transition. Compound 3 is soluble in water but insoluble in common organic solvents such as ethanol, methanol, and ethyl acetate.

elements.content: The chemistry of magnesium coordination networks is driven by ionic forces rather than covalent bonding. The preference toward ionic bonding of magnesium leads to the absence of secondary building units (SBUs) with dominance of crystal packing forces. As a consequence, the network topology is strongly dependent on the nature of organic linkers and solvents and less dependent on the nature of the magnesium metal center. Because of the dimensionless nature of its bond, magnesium is also highly susceptible to easily change its coordination environment after desolvation, though the ionic nature of the Mg–O bond might help in adsorption of certain polar gases, such as carbon monoxide, hydrogen sulfide, and ammonia.

elements.content: Four magnesium based coordination networks were synthesized using different solvents under solvothermal conditions. Compounds 1, 3, and 4 form a 3-D open network with the presence of channels within them while compound 2 is a layered structure with isolated magnesium polyhedra. The relative coordination ability of the solvents with the metal center plays a vital role in determining the topologies of the networks. It was determined that water has the highest affinity to coordinate with the magnesium metal centers, followed by DMF, while solvents such as methanol and ethanol tend not to coordinate with the metal center in the presence of the water and DMF, respectively. The detailed characterization of 1–4 by single crystal XRD and thermal analysis shed light on the chemistry of magnesium–pyridinedicarboxylate systems. We are continuing to explore the chemistry of magnesium based coordination networks using different organic linkers and synthetic conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Four magnesium based coordination networks were synthesized using different solvents under solvothermal conditions. Compounds 1, 3, and 4 form a 3-D open network with the presence of channels within them while compound 2 is a layered structure with isolated magnesium polyhedra. The relative coordination ability of the solvents with the metal center plays a vital role in determining the topologies of the networks. It was determined that water has the highest affinity to coordinate with the magnesium metal centers, followed by DMF, while solvents such as methanol and ethanol tend not to coordinate with the metal center in the presence of the water and DMF, respectively. The detailed characterization of 1-4 by single crystal XRD and thermal analysis shed light on the chemistry of magnesium-pyridinedicarboxylate systems. We are continuing to explore the chemistry of magnesium based coordination networks using different organic linkers and synthetic conditions.

elements.content: Figures S1–S20 (showing PXRD data, ORTEP diagrams, the local environments of the Mg ions in the investigated compounds, the zigzag chain of Mg octahedra in 1, and 2-D packing arrangements) and crystallographic information files (CIFs) for compounds 1–4. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
A typical synthesis includes a mixture of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O (0.258 g) and 3,5-PDC (0.17 g) dissolved in 9.5 g of DMF and stirred for 3 h to achieve homogeneity [molar ratio of metal salt/ligand/solvent = 1:1:130]. The resultant solution was heated for 5 days at 100 °C, and the product (yield: 60% based on Mg, 0.172 g) was collected as needle shaped crystals by filtration and washed by DMF.

Synthesis of Compound <bold>2</bold>, Mg(3,5-PDC)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>

Compound 2 was synthesized from a mixture of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O (0.255 g) and 3,5-PDC (0.167 g) dissolved in 6 g of ethanol, which was stirred for 2 h [molar ratio of metal salt/ligand/solvent = 1:1:130]. The resultant solution was heated for 5 days at 100 °C. The product was collected as needle shaped crystals (yield: 50% based on Mg, 0.112 g) by filtration and rinsed with ethanol.

Synthesis of Compound <bold>3</bold>, Mg(3,5-PDC)(H<sub>2</sub>O)·(H<sub>2</sub>O)

Compound 3 was synthesized by dissolving Mg(NO3)2·6H2O (0.257 g) and 3,5-PDC (0.168 g) in a mixture of DMF (4.7 g) and ethanol (2.99 g) and stirred for 1 h [molar ratio of metal salt/ligand/DMF/ethanol = 1:1:65:65]. The resulting solution was heated for 5 days at 100 °C. The product was obtained as crystalline material (yield 60% based on Mg, 0.135 g) by filtration and washed with ethanol.

Synthesis of Compound <bold>4</bold>, Mg<sub>4</sub>(3,5-PDC)<sub>4</sub>(DMF)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>·2DMF·4.5H<sub>2</sub>O

Compound 4 was synthesized by dissolving Mg(NO3)2·6H2O (0.261 g) and 3,5-PDC (0.171 g) in a mixture of DMF (4.7 g) and ethanol (2.08 g) and stirred for 2 h to achieve homogeneity [molar ratio of metal salt/ligand/DMF/methanol = 1:1:65:65]. The resulting solution was heated for 5 days at 100 °C. A yellow phase was collected by filtration as a side product along with needle shaped crystals of compound 4. Efforts to obtain a pure phase of compound 4 by (a) increasing reaction temperature or (b) increasing solvent ratio were not successful.

Compound 3 was synthesized by dissolving Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.257 g) and 3,5-PDC (0.168 g) in a mixture of DMF (4.7 g) and ethanol (2.99 g) and stirred for 1 h [molar ratio of metal salt/ligand/DMF/ethanol = 1:1:65:65]. The resulting solution was heated for 5 days at 100 °C. The product was obtained as crystalline material (yield 60% based on Mg, 0.135 g) by filtration and washed with ethanol.

cln_elements.content:
Three magnesium based metal–organic frameworks, Mg3(3,5-PDC)3(DMF)3·DMF [1], Mg(3,5-PDC)(H2O)·(H2O) [3], and Mg4(3,5-PDC)4(DMF)2(H2O)2·2DMF·4.5H2O [4], and a 2-D coordination polymer, [Mg(3,5-PDC)(H2O)2] [2] [PDC = pyridinedicarboxylate], were synthesized using a combination of DMF, methanol, ethanol, and water. Compound 1 [space group P21/n, a = 12.3475(5) Å, b = 11.1929(5) Å, c = 28.6734(12) Å, β = 98.8160(10)°, V = 3916.0(3) Å3] consists of a combination of isolated and corner-sharing magnesium octahedra connected by the organic linkers to form a 3-D network with a 12.2 Å × 4.6 Å 1-D channel. The channel contains coordinated and free DMF molecules. In compound 2 [space group C2/c, a = 9.964(5) Å, b = 12.0694(6) Å, c = 7.2763(4) Å, β = 106.4970(6)°, V = 836.70(6) Å3], PDC connects isolated seven coordinated magnesium polyhedra into a layered structure. Compound 3 [space group P6122, a = 11.479(1) Å, c = 14.735(3) Å, V = 1681.7(4) Å3] (previously reported) contains isolated magnesium octahedra connected by the organic linker with each other forming a 3D network. Compound 4 [space group P21/c, a = 13.7442(14) Å, b = 14.2887(15) Å, c = 14.1178(14) Å, β = 104.912(2)°, V = 2679.2(5) Å3] also exhibits a 3D network based on isolated magnesium octahedra with square cavities containing both disordered DMF and water molecules. The structural topologies originate due to the variable coordination ability of solvent molecules with the metal center. Water molecules coordinate with the magnesium metal centers preferably over other polar solvents (DMF, methanol, ethanol) used to synthesize the coordination networks. Despite testing multiple desolvation routes, we were unable to measure BET surface areas greater than 51.9 m2/g for compound 1.

The isolated magnesium octahedra is connected with the dimeric corner sharing magnesium octahedra through carboxylate oxygen atoms along the [010] direction (Figure S8 of the ). The magnesium polyhedra are further connected in the [100] and [001] directions through pyridyl nitrogen and carboxylate oxygen atoms of PDC linker forming channels filled with both coordinated and free DMF molecules. The solvent molecules exhibit various degrees of disorder. The dimensionalities of the channels are on average 12.2 Å × 4.6 Å along the [010] direction when calculated based on van der Waals radii in the absence of both coordinated and free DMF molecules in the channel. Calculations using PLATON indicate a 51.5% (2018.2 Å3) void space after removal of coordinated and free DMF molecules from the channel.

Each magnesium polyhedron is connected to each other one in corner sharing fashion through a carboxylate oxygen atom (O7), forming a dimer. Each dimer is further connected by functional groups (carboxylate oxygen atoms and pyridyl nitrogen) of the organic linkers in all three crystallographic directions. Such an arrangement leads to the formation of a diamond shaped 1-D channel with average size 8.5 Å × 3.5 Å. Coordinated and uncoordinated solvent molecules including DMF and water are present in the channel. PLATON indicates a 32.1% (858.7 Å3) void space after removal of free DMF and water molecules from the channel.

Thermal stabilities of compounds 1–3 were investigated using the combination of TGA and DSC techniques under N2 atmosphere. Compound 1 shows a ready removal of both coordinated and free DMF molecules up to 325 °C (calculated, 32.3%; observed, 33.1%), followed by pyrolysis of the ligand over 425 °C. Compound 2, on the other hand, shows a stepwise decomposition pathway (Figure 8). The first weight loss that occurs at 225 °C is due to the removal of water molecules (calculated, 15.9 wt %; observed, 16.1 wt %), followed by a stable plateau to 515 °C, where pyrolysis of the ligand occurs. Compound 3 shows similar two step decomposition pathways. In the first step, coordinated and free water molecules are removed (calculated, 15.9%; observed, 16%) in a continuous fashion within 225 °C. This step is followed by a stable plateau up to 520 °C followed by pyrolysis of the organic linker.

Porous alkali- and alkaline-earth metal carboxylates are scarce. As compound 1 possesses a theoretical 51.5% (2018.2 Å3) void space, we attempted to activate a sample under dynamic vacuum at 200 °C. The powder diffraction pattern of the desolvated sample shows poor crystallinity (Figure S17 of the ) and a low BET surface area of 51.9 m2/g and a Langmuir surface area of 69.7 m2/g. The small surface area indicates destruction of network, which is also supported by the PXRD data. In a few reported cases, magnesium networks show nonporosity toward N2, due to smaller pore size, but show permanent porosity toward other gases, e.g. O2 and CO2 due to their smaller kinetic diameters. In this case, it is highly unlikely, as compound 1 does show adsorption of N2, as evident in the BET/Langmuir studies. Further, the PXRD pattern of desolvated compound 1 does not show retention of network.
